channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Senators reach deal to reopen the government. And, countries gather for climate talks
item.description: Several Senate Democrats break ranks to join Republicans in a deal to reopen the government. And, world leaders gather in Brazil for a major climate conference, but the U.S. is not expected to attend.
item.content:encoded:
Several Senate Democrats break ranks to join Republicans in a deal to reopen the government. And, world leaders gather in Brazil for a major climate conference, but the U.S. is not expected to attend.

(Image credit: Anna Rose Layden)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: Trump grants pardons to Giuliani, Meadows, others linked to 2020 election efforts
item.description: The pardons include 77 allies tied to efforts to overturn the 2020 election, including Rudy Giuliani, former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, and former Trump attorney Sidney Powell.
item.content:encoded:
The pardons include 77 allies tied to efforts to overturn the 2020 election, including Rudy Giuliani, former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows, and former Trump attorney Sidney Powell.

(Image credit: Seth Wenig/)
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Rosman

item.title: Countries are gathering for climate negotiations. Here's where the U.S. stands
item.description: Under President Trump, the U.S. has taken steps to roll back climate policies. Here are six significant changes.
item.content:encoded:
Under President Trump, the U.S. has taken steps to roll back climate policies. Here are six significant changes.

(Image credit: Wagner Meier)
item.dc:creator: Alejandra Borunda

item.title: People want to avoid ultra-processed foods. But experts struggle to define them
item.description: The evidence that ultra-processed foods are bad for us is piling up. But efforts to reduce their role in our diets face a big hurdle: experts can't agree on what they are and which to target.
item.content:encoded:
The evidence that ultra-processed foods are bad for us is piling up. But efforts to reduce their role in our diets face a big hurdle: experts can't agree on what they are and which to target.

(Image credit: ruzanna)
item.dc:creator: Maria Godoy

item.title: Alaska's public schools can serve as emergency shelters. The buildings are in crisis
item.description: Alaska's public schools are being used as emergency shelters, though many of the buildings are crumbling.
item.content:encoded:
Alaska's public schools are being used as emergency shelters, though many of the buildings are crumbling.

(Image credit: Eric Stone)
item.dc:creator: Emily Schwing

item.title: In an encrypted group chat, National Guard members question Trump deployments
item.description: As President Trump's call for National Guard deployments rings out across the U.S., a small contingent of Ohio guard members is quietly expressing concern in an encrypted group chat.
item.content:encoded:
As President Trump's call for National Guard deployments rings out across the U.S., a small contingent of Ohio guard members is quietly expressing concern in an encrypted group chat.

(Image credit: Al Drago)
item.dc:creator: Kat Lonsdorf

item.title: Typhoon Fung-wong leaves 4 dead and 1.4 million displaced in the Philippines
item.description: Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the Philippines after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million.
item.content:encoded:
Typhoon Fung-wong blew out of the Philippines after setting off floods and landslides, knocking out power to entire provinces, killing at least four people and displacing more than 1.4 million.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Senators take first step toward reopening the government after historic shutdown
item.description: The Senate voted late Sunday evening on a compromise that could reopen the government following the longest shutdown in history.
item.content:encoded:
The Senate voted late Sunday evening on a compromise that could reopen the government following the longest shutdown in history.

(Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)
item.dc:creator: Claudia Grisales

item.title: MLB pitchers Emmanuel Clase and Luis Ortiz charged with taking bribes to rig pitches
item.description: Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they'd throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes.
item.content:encoded:
Two Major League Baseball pitchers have been indicted on charges they took bribes to give bettors advance notice of the types of pitches they'd throw and intentionally tossed balls instead of strikes.

(Image credit: Sue Ogrocki)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Some UPS and FedEx planes are grounded. What does that mean for holiday shipping?
item.description: UPS and FedEx's fleets of MD-11 planes are grounded, which can each carry thousands of packages. Logistics experts say some cargo could shift to passenger planes, trains and trucks.
item.content:encoded:
UPS and FedEx's fleets of MD-11 planes are grounded, which can each carry thousands of packages. Logistics experts say some cargo could shift to passenger planes, trains and trucks.

(Image credit: Wilfredo Lee)
item.dc:creator: Chandelis Duster
